entry.title: Proteotoxic stress response drives T cell exhaustion and immune evasion (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Proteotoxic stress response drives T cell exhaustion and immune evasion

A proteotoxic stress response specific to exhausted T cells, governed by AKT signaling and accompanied by increased protein translation, represents a mechanistic vulnerability and a new therapeutic target to improve cancer immunotherapies.

  • Yi Wang
  • Anjun Ma
  • Zihai Li
ArticleOpen Access01 Oct 2025

entry.title: Kirigami-inspired parachutes with programmable reconfiguration (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Kirigami-inspired parachutes with programmable reconfiguration

A thin planar disc designed with appropriately patterned cuts transforms itself, due to air flow effects, into an effective parachute exhibiting good positional stability, regardless of its initial orientation.

  • Danick Lamoureux
  • Jérémi Fillion
  • David Melancon
Article01 Oct 2025

entry.title: Efferocytic remodelling of pancreatic islet macrophages by limited β-cell death (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Efferocytic remodelling of pancreatic islet macrophages by limited β-cell death

Enrichment for efferocytic macrophages in the islets of Langerhans promotes the accumulation of anergic-like CD4+ T cells and dampens autoimmune diabetes.

  • Pavel N. Zakharov
  • Chanchal S. Chowdhury
  • Kodi S. Ravichandran
Article01 Oct 2025

entry.title: Dietary cysteine enhances intestinal stemness via CD8+ T cell-derived IL-22 (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Dietary cysteine enhances intestinal stemness via CD8+ T cell-derived IL-22

Dietary cysteine enhances intestinal stem cell-mediated intestinal repair following injury by promoting CD8 T cell-regenerative immune responses.

  • Fangtao Chi
  • Qiming Zhang
  • Ömer H. Yilmaz
Article01 Oct 2025

entry.title: A new paradigm for outer membrane protein biogenesis in the Bacteroidota (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
A new paradigm for outer membrane protein biogenesis in the Bacteroidota

Structural and biochemical studies of the β-barrel-assembly machinery from Flavobacterium johnsoniae reveal a subunit composition and assembly that are distinct from those of the canonical Escherichia coli complex.

  • Xiaolong Liu
  • Luis Orenday Tapia
  • Ben C. Berks
ArticleOpen Access01 Oct 2025

entry.title: Signal amplification in a solid-state sensor through asymmetric many-body echo (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Signal amplification in a solid-state sensor through asymmetric many-body echo

The experimental demonstration of many-body signal amplification in a solid-state, room-temperature quantum sensor is reported.

  • Haoyang Gao
  • Leigh S. Martin
  • Mikhail D. Lukin
ArticleOpen Access01 Oct 2025

entry.title: Heat-rechargeable computation in DNA logic circuits and neural networks (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Heat-rechargeable computation in DNA logic circuits and neural networks

Heat recharges enzyme-free DNA circuits, enabling complex logic operations and neural networks to perform multiple computations, offering a universal energy source for molecular machines and advancing autonomous behaviours in artificial chemical systems.

  • Tianqi Song
  • Lulu Qian
ArticleOpen Access01 Oct 2025

entry.title: Monoclonal antibodies protect against pandrug-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Monoclonal antibodies protect against pandrug-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae

Capsule-specific human monoclonal antibodies are protective against bloodstream infection by Klebsiella pneumoniae sequence type 147 in a mouse model of septicaemia, and could provide a useful strategy against pathogens with antimicrobial resistance.

  • Emanuele Roscioli
  • Vittoria Zucconi Galli Fonseca
  • Rino Rappuoli
Article01 Oct 2025

entry.title: Polygenic and developmental profiles of autism differ by age at diagnosis (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Polygenic and developmental profiles of autism differ by age at diagnosis

A study of several longitudinal birth cohorts and cross-sectional cohorts finds only moderate overlap in genetic variants between autism that is diagnosed earlier and that diagnosed later, so they may represent aetiologically different conditions.

  • Xinhe Zhang
  • Jakob Grove
  • Varun Warrier
ArticleOpen Access01 Oct 2025

entry.title: Tracking clonal evolution during treatment in ovarian cancer using cell-free DNA (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Tracking clonal evolution during treatment in ovarian cancer using cell-free DNA

A combined sequencing technique assesses 18 patients with high-grade serous ovarian cancer over a multi-year period from diagnosis to recurrence and shows drug resistance typically arises from selective expansion of one or a few clones present at diagnosis.

  • Marc J. Williams
  • Ignacio Vázquez-García
  • Sohrab P. Shah
ArticleOpen Access01 Oct 2025

entry.title: Connecting chemical and protein sequence space to predict biocatalytic reactions (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Connecting chemical and protein sequence space to predict biocatalytic reactions

A two-phase machine-learning-based tool making use of high-throughput experimentation is introduced to examine the connections between chemical and protein sequence space and predict productive biocatalytic reactions among substrate and enzyme pairs.

  • Alexandra E. Paton
  • Daniil A. Boiko
  • Alison R. H. Narayan
ArticleOpen Access01 Oct 2025

entry.title: Mosaic anatomy in an early fossil squamate (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Mosaic anatomy in an early fossil squamate

Breugnathair elgolensis gen. et sp. nov., an early squamate identified from a newly discovered Middle Jurassic skeleton on the Isle of Skye, provides new evidence on the origins of snakes.

  • Roger B. J. Benson
  • Stig A. Walsh
  • Susan E. Evans
ArticleOpen Access01 Oct 2025

entry.title: Doughnut of social and planetary boundaries monitors a world out of balance (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Doughnut of social and planetary boundaries monitors a world out of balance

A revised ‘Doughnut’ providing a visual assessment of trends in social deprivation and planetary degradation over the past two decades shows more than doubling of global GDP accompanied by accelerating ecological overshoot but only a modest reduction in human deprivation.

  • Andrew L. Fanning
  • Kate Raworth
AnalysisOpen Access01 Oct 2025

entry.title: A human-specific regulatory mechanism revealed in a pre-implantation model (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
A human-specific regulatory mechanism revealed in a pre-implantation model

Genetic manipulation of blastoids reveals the role of recently emerged transposable elements and genes in human development.

  • Raquel Fueyo
  • Sicong Wang
  • Joanna Wysocka
ArticleOpen Access01 Oct 2025

entry.title: The Panoptes system uses decoy cyclic nucleotides to defend against phage (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
The Panoptes system uses decoy cyclic nucleotides to defend against phage

The Panoptes antiphage system defends bacteria by detecting phage-encoded counter-defences that sequester cyclic nucleotide signals, triggering membrane disruption and highlighting a broader strategy of sensing immune evasion through second-messenger surveillance.

  • Ashley E. Sullivan
  • Ali Nabhani
  • Benjamin R. Morehouse
ArticleOpen Access01 Oct 2025

entry.title: A miniature CRISPR–Cas10 enzyme confers immunity by inhibitory signalling (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
A miniature CRISPR–Cas10 enzyme confers immunity by inhibitory signalling

Panoptes, an anti-phage defence system against virus-mediated immune suppression, is revealed.

  • Erin E. Doherty
  • Benjamin A. Adler
  • Jennifer A. Doudna
ArticleOpen Access01 Oct 2025

entry.title: Long-distance remote epitaxy (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Long-distance remote epitaxy

Experimental evidence demonstrates long-distance remote epitaxial interactions of thin films even through thick amorphous carbon buffer layers and shows that these can be induced through dislocations in the substrate.

  • Ru Jia
  • Yan Xin
  • Jian Shi
Article01 Oct 2025

entry.title: Autoimmune response to C9orf72 protein in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Autoimmune response to C9orf72 protein in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

An analysis of T cell responses in people with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis shows that the C9orf72 antigen is a key target of autoimmune responses in the disease, and identifies C9orf72 epitopes that are recognized.

  • Tanner Michaelis
  • Cecilia S. Lindestam Arlehamn
  • Alessandro Sette
ArticleOpen Access01 Oct 2025

entry.title: Spin squeezing in an ensemble of nitrogen–vacancy centres in diamond (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Spin squeezing in an ensemble of nitrogen–vacancy centres in diamond

An ensemble of spins from nitrogen–vacancy centres in diamonds is prepared in a spin-squeezed state.

  • Weijie Wu
  • Emily J. Davis
  • Norman Y. Yao
